title: Trump Suggests Link Between Ukraine Aid Review and Pressure Campaign
text:
President Trump on Monday suggested a link between his administration’s review of military aid to Ukraine and his efforts to persuade the Ukrainian president to pursue damaging material on Democratic front-runner Joe Biden, as scrutiny of his dealings with Kiev have reverberated around Washington in recent days.

“It’s very important to talk about corruption,” Mr. Trump said at a United Nations event. “If you don’t talk about corruption, why would you give money to a country that you think is corrupt?”

Congress had agreed to send $250 million to Ukraine to defend it against Russian aggression, but the Trump administration for weeks delayed sending the money, vexing lawmakers who were kept in the dark about why. The administration released the aid earlier this month, and lawmakers have called for an investigation into who directed that delay and whether it was related to pressure on Ukraine from the president and his personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani.

Ukrainian officials earlier this month expressed concern to U.S. senators that the aid had been held up as a penalty for resisting pressure to investigate Mr. Biden.

“They worried the aid that was being cut off to Ukraine by the president was a consequence for their unwillingness at the time to investigate the Bidens,” said Sen. Chris Murphy (D., Conn.), who earlier this month met in Ukraine with President Volodymyr Zelensky and other officials.

The Ukrainian embassy in Washington didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment on Mr. Murphy’s remarks.

Sunday, Mr. Trump confirmed a Wall Street Journal report that he discussed Mr. Biden with Mr. Zelensky in a July phone conversation. Messrs. Trump and Giuliani have pressed for an inquiry into Mr. Biden’s anticorruption efforts in the country while he was vice president and while his son Hunter Biden had business interests there. Ukraine’s prosecutor general at the time said earlier this year he had no evidence of wrongdoing by Mr. Biden or his son. On Saturday, Joe Biden said he had never discussed with his son any overseas business dealings and accused Mr. Trump of abusing his office.

Mr. Trump on Monday again tried to revive the accusations of impropriety against the Bidens in Ukraine. The president also said he wasn’t concerned that his conversation with Mr. Zelensky could fuel calls for impeachment. White House officials, meanwhile, said they are reviewing whether to release a transcript of the president’s call with Mr. Zelensky.

Democrats are now raising questions about whether the president successfully enlisted others in the Trump administration to carry out the pressure campaign. The U.S. Embassy in Ukraine told Mr. Murphy earlier this month that it wasn’t involved in demanding the Ukrainian president mount an investigation, a statement that Mr. Murphy took as a sign that diplomats had refused to get involved because they believed such conduct was improper.

“I’m now concerned that I didn’t get the full story,” Mr. Murphy said. “The fact that [Secretary of State Mike] Pompeo is now refusing to say whether the State Department was involved may suggest that there was some work being done by others in the administration beyond the president himself.”

A State Department spokesman said Monday that at the request of Andriy Yermak, a top aide to Mr. Zelensky, the U.S. special representative for Ukraine negotiations put Mr. Yermak in touch with Mr. Giuliani. The spokesman said Mr. Giuliani was acting “in a personal capacity as a lawyer for President Trump” and didn’t speak on behalf of the U.S. government.

The examination of Mr. Trump’s dealings with his Ukrainian counterpart is likely to escalate this week as Congress continues to probe a whistleblower complaint concerning Mr. Trump, an aspect of which involves the Ukraine call, according to a person familiar with the matter.

On Monday, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D., N.Y.) sent a letter to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) urging him to take “immediate action” to stop Mr. Trump from withholding the complaint from Congress and to request that the White House to release a transcript of the call with Mr. Zelensky.

The whistleblower complaint was submitted last month to the inspector general of the intelligence community, who deemed it a significant matter of “urgent concern.” Federal whistleblowing law generally dictates that such a complaint should be sent to the congressional intelligence committees, but Joseph Maguire, the acting director of national intelligence, has refused to do so.

Mr. Maguire is to appear this week before both the Senate and House intelligence committees, where he will be asked about his decision not to share the complaint.

—Rebecca Elliott, Siobhan Hughes and Courtney McBride contributed to this article.

Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
description: President Trump suggested a link between his administration’s review of military aid to Ukraine and his efforts to persuade the Ukrainian president to pursue damaging material on rival Joe Biden.
